6492: Alaborn Zealot.author: Cactmoore
6492: Alaborn Zealot.text_parsed:
Personally, I prefer the identical Loyal Sentry, at least because of its lack of a totally non-thematic-for-Magic gun.
You can use a card like this to intimidate your opponent: they will play differently if they know you can blow up their big beastie if they attack with it. Now, that can have both its advantages and disadvantages, but that much is really in how you play. Plus, as others have pointed out, it's a lot more reusable than other cheap White removal like Swords to Plowshares, for example.
Anyway, 5/5 for the card, but -1 for the art, bringing it to a 4/5.

6496: Trokin High Guard.author: Madrai
6496: Trokin High Guard.text_parsed: I started magic with Portal: The Second Age. I loved the swords and sorcery, and this guy was my favorite card. He just looked amazing. A knight clad in bright armor, dual wielding a keen sword and a smoking pistol. Looking back now, I know he was underpowered for a white card with no effects, but that's how Portal was. It was a magic for beginners, and it was perfect for me as a kid. 5 out of 5 for Nostalgia.

6496: Trokin High Guard.author: MrCookie
6496: Trokin High Guard.text_parsed:
In terms of what you're buying for a four drop, he's not that great. But then most portal cards were sub-par intentionally. The few cards from portal that accidentally were powerful were just that, accidents.

I've seen so much hate on other Second Age cards for having guns and "taking away from the feel". Which I think is damn silly. Dominaria has gone through three separate medieval eras before everything went all post apocalypse. Thousands of years of innovation and development. But nobody has developed fire arms? Nobody's technical innovations moved into Renascence era building? Its not like the societies of Dominaria have replaced all their technology with magic. Magic users are uncommon. You get maybe one shamans or cleric or mage in a village.

So yeah. There's my rant. Meh card. Great artwork.

6497: Wild Griffin.author: BastianQoU
6497: Wild Griffin.text_parsed:
The flavor text is part of a little poem across three other cards (at least as far as I was able to find.)

Tidal Surge: Four little goblins, trapped by the sea. One teased a serpent, and then there were three.
Ogre Taskmaster: Three little goblins, enjoying their brew. One bumped an ogre, and then there were two.
Wild Griffin: Two little goblins, out in the sun. Down came a griffin, and then there was one.
Tremor: One little goblin shook up the ground. When the dust cleared, no one was found.

Anyways, it's interesting that due to the way the Portal cards were printed, the wall's restriction didn't take the form of reminder text but rather rules text. It had the static ability "Walls can't attack"! Of course that wasn't what was intended (and this little bit of rules obscura has since been swept away with the advent of Defender) but R&D's Secret Lair is always there to save the day. It keeps all of your opponent's changelings from attacking! Change the wall's creature type and you can send that bloodthirsty 0/4 charging in ("feel its justice!)" The possibilities are endless!

6507: Temple Elder.author: luca_barelli
6507: Temple Elder.text_parsed: Why are there these dumb limitations on tap abilities in Portal? The designers for these sets should have been fired.
6507: Temple Elder.text_posted: Why are there these dumb limitations on tap abilities in Portal? The designers for these sets should have been fired.

6507: Temple Elder.author: tavaritz
6507: Temple Elder.text_parsed: Portal didn't have special timing rules. You could respond to a spell only if the card you wanted to use said so. With no stack and no actual fast effects these tap abilities were more or less the same we have on some permanents even today: 'use only when you could cast a sorcery'. You cannot use that templating on Portal cards because there were sorceries that could be cast during attack and during opponents turn.

6509: Armored Griffin.author: jeff-heikkinen
6509: Armored Griffin.text_parsed: For a while, there was a tendency for White to get one or two 2/2 fliers with another decent ability for 4 mana in nearly every set; many of these were Griffins, like this one. This is better than most of them, with *two* "other decent abilities" - Vigilance, and an extra point of toughness. But even with that advantage, this card follows the same pattern as all such creatures - solid in Limited but nowhere near Constructed-worthy. The particular problem with this one is that, until its recent appearance in ME2, it was never in a format that had Limited competition on a regular basis.
6509: Armored Griffin.text_posted: For a while, there was a tendency for White to get one or two 2/2 fliers with another decent ability for 4 mana in nearly every set; many of these were Griffins, like this one. But even with that advantage, this card follows the same pattern as all such creatures - solid in Limited but nowhere near Constructed-worthy. 6510: Bargain.author: iUseBreakOpen
6510: Bargain.text_parsed:
Terrible card. Strangely though, I think I understand Wizard's thought process when making this card. At the time this was made, Healing Salve was the base line. Playing 2 Healing Salves is trading 2 mana and 2 card advantage for 6 life. This is also 2 card advantage, so you are basically paying 1 mana more for 1 life more. Unfortunately: 1) Healing Salve is weak by today's standards and 2) most of Healing Salves playability came from the ability to save creatures.

It makes me wonder, how much life would it have to give before people would play it? Would people use it if it gave 10 life? How about 15 life?

Terrible card. Strangely though, I think I understand Wizard's thought process when making this card. At the time this was made, [autocard]Healing Salve[/autocard] was the base line. Playing 2 Healing Salves is trading 2 mana and 2 card advantage for 6 life. This is also 2 card advantage, so you are basically paying 1 mana more for 1 life more. Unfortunately: 1) Healing Salve is weak by today's standards and 2) most of Healing Salves playability came from the ability to save creatures.

It makes me wonder, how much life would it have to give before people would play it? Would people use it if it gave 10 life? How about 15 life?

6519: Just Fate.author: scumbling1
6519: Just Fate.text_parsed:
"So you can only use this to kill your own creature? since this is a sorcery"

Some sorceries from Portal bent the timing rules and allowed them to be played during an opponent's turn. They have since been errataed to be instants, which I feel is a better decision than allowing certain exceptions to the rules.

But no matter if it's an instant or a sorcery with special rules, you can't ever kill your own creatures with this card. You can only cast it after you've been attacked, at which time you can't have attacking creatures of your own.
6519: Just Fate.text_posted:
[i]"So you can only use this to kill your own creature? since this is a sorcery"[/i]

6531: Tidal Surge.text_parsed:
Four little goblins, trapped by the sea. One teased a serpent, and then there were three.
Three little goblins, enjoying their brew. One bumped an ogre, and then there were two.

Old 5-color aggro decks would target a fetchland with it's "drawback" ability, then sacrifice the fetch. If you have two fetchlands to target and then sacrifice, you would not have to return any lands.

It's no longer a casual card due to price, but if you had them already, before they sky-rocketed in price, you can abuse the drawback with Exploration, Fastbond, and Horn of Greed

6544: Coastal Wizard.author: Cybertronian
6544: Coastal Wizard.text_parsed:
It reads a lot better with the updated text: {T}: Return Coastal Wizard and another target creature to their owners' hands. Activate this ability only during your turn, before attackers are declared. This card is a good way of taking a nasty blocker (such as a Leviathan or a nasty Wall of Frost - or Fire) before swinging with something that wouldn't have the juice to jump said hurdle.

If Wizards was allowed to re-rule this card, I'd agree with Kurraga, except that I wouldn't give it Haste. On the other hand, if Haste and Flash were off the table, I think it shouldn't be limited to the owner's turn.
In short:
{2}{U}{U} (1/1)
{T}: Return "Coastal Wizard" and another target creature to their owners' hands. Activate this ability before attackers are declared.

This would make CW a great means of removing a monstrous attacker and defender from play in the nick of time.
6544: Coastal Wizard.text_posted:

This card is a good way of taking a nasty blocker (such as a Leviathan or a nasty [autocard]Wall of Frost[/autocard] - [autocard multiverseid="136284"]or Fire[/autocard]) before swinging with something that wouldn't have the juice to jump said hurdle.

If Wizards was allowed to re-rule this card, I'd agree with Kurraga, except that I wouldn't give it Haste. On the other hand, if Haste [i]and[/i] Flash were off the table, I think it shouldn't be limited to the owner's turn. 
In short:
{2}{U}{U}  (1/1)
{T}: Return "Coastal Wizard" and another target creature to their owners' hands. Activate this ability before attackers are declared.

This would make CW a great means of removing a monstrous attacker [b]and[/b] defender from play in the nick of time.

This card, I don't own it, but I perfectly recall when I opened a Phantom Warrior in a Weatherlight pack, and I was like "What the f**k!", in a positive way, and then I thought a little something like "But this wouldn't be too much non-interactive?". The irony... However, this is one of my favourite blue creature of all times! I won a 9th Edition Draft, at the pre-release, enchanting the Phantom Warrior with Spirit Link, along with Serra Angel and Icy Manipulator. It was one of my most successful pre-release, and I won 9 9th edition pack, one for each language Magic was translated into. It was glorious!

And about the Pirate tribe, I wonder why R&D didn't bring it back during Zendikar block. I think it would fit quite well! I hope to see them come back, soon...!

For me, this is a easy 5/5

6554: Moaning Spirit.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
6554: Moaning Spirit.text_parsed:
Certainly not the most exciting creature in the world, and nothing remarkable for its cost, either. As Duskdale points out, it's a card that has been done before, and has been redone since.

What I do like about it, though, is the flavour behind the creature. M:TG doesn't have "ghost" as a creature type any more, but this creature reminds me of some of the black creatures I used to find creepiest: Lost Soul and Bog Wraith. Black magic has called up the spirits of some hapless people and pressed them to service. We know almost nothing about them - they're hidden in robes - and only creepy little rhymes attest to their danger.

The same is true for Moaning Spirit - she looks just a little off, and there's no way to know in what way she's dangerous until it's probably too late!

EDIT:
@tavaritz: You have to know the multiverseid of the card you want to link to - usually it's the number at the end of the Gatherer page's URL. Then, instead of doing (autocard)Lost Soul(/autocard), you would put (autocard multiverseid="XXXX")random text(/autocard), where XXXX is the multiverse ID of whatever card you want to link to.

6555: Swarm of Rats.author: Mode
6555: Swarm of Rats.text_parsed:
yeah, Portal reminder texts are sometimes pretty funny, see Wrath of God portal version for instance.
I got one of these, but the bold font annoys me a bit. I'd like to see a black-bordered Swarm of Rats without bold font using the "new" design (you can't really call it new anymore since 8th edition design change is about seven years back).

I think what's even more odd about this card is the flavor: It represents all your Rats, yet in the end it's just another seperate creature:
If you have two other Rats for example, this one is a 3/1. Now you can just attack with your Swarm of Rats, and the other two Rats that are considered part of the swarm remain untapped. The swarm dies, and the other rats remain unharmed.

6568: Foul Spirit.author: Fert12334
6568: Foul Spirit.text_parsed:
Ugh, sometimes i really hate the oracle wording. Destroying one of your lands and sacrificing one of your lands are two completely different things. For example, this could easily be combo-ed with Darksteel Citadel to avoid the loss of a land. Not like that breaks the card or anything, but it is changed by the new wording.

Anyways - about the card as it is, losing a land for a 3/2 flier doesn't seem worth it for 3 mana considering how much it's going to set you back. Well, at least it has a somewhat useful creature type.

2.5/5

6569: Dark Offering.author: Stuflames
6569: Dark Offering.text_parsed:
Planeswalker: "DEMON LORDS, I SACRIFICE THIS HOLY ANGEL TO THEE THAT I MIGHT BE STRONGER!!!"
Demon: "Oh, hai. Uhh, are you sure that's your angel that you're sacrificing? I'm looking over the paperwork here and it appears to belong to the other planesw-"
*Planeswalker slips 5 extra mana into the Demon's hand*
Demon: "-Aaand we're good here! We'll just take your angel here into the abyss, you take your life, and have yourself a great morn- I mean afternoon! Hah, this day is just flying by, toodles!"

And that's how we get the name and cost of Dark Offering.

6574: Hidden Horror.author: Aburaishi
6574: Hidden Horror.text_parsed: This guy's actually really good for decks that use things like Unearth and Rise From the Grave (which are pretty much half the black decks in existence). You get a 4/4 for 3, and a 3 CMC creature for 1 or a 6+ CMC creature for 5. In fact, he's even affected by Unearth, which means you could play him, destroy him, then bring him back if you don't have any creatures in your hand. This guy facilitates resurrection very effectively on a body bigger than his CMC should allow. If I had a black deck, I'd definitely use 'em.

6576: Dakmor Sorceress.author: Kserwin

This girl is always out of Bolt range, but her power still grows/decreases, which is what I'm mainly after. She does lack Flying, though. Or any form of evasion. But considering EDH, I'm pretty glad this card exists. Nightmare, Korlash, and this... who doesn't like three creatures that get buffed from Swamps? More things to benefit from my Liliana of the Dark Realms, if she survives! Both cards are better in different situations, but I find both to be quite solid, and worth a spot in some decks.

6591: Lava Axe.author: fissionessence
6591: Lava Axe.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #19 - 7/16/2011 - Lava Axe

The random function popped up the Portal Second Age version of this card. After a quick perusal of all one thousand printings, I have to wonder why this art only appeared once. The dynamic energy of the axe being thrown (as seen as recently as the M12 printing) is pretty nice, but it's nothing compared to the epicness of this Portal Second Age axe, dripping with lava over a molten pool in the midst of a dungeon, complete with stalactites and chains. Come on. I can only assume there was some legal snafu preventing them from reprinting this picture.

As a card, I've never quite been able to figure it out. In limited, I might put it in as one of my last few cards, but it seems scary to run two. Although I suppose a deck with four or five could just be brutal. There just seems to be a huge disparity between when it lets you get a huge amount of reach in a game you might have lost, versus when it is completely irrelevant and you just wish you could have had a Wind Drake or something.

Also, I don't usually like the silly flavor text red cards many times get, but the, "Catch!" line on many versions of this card is just miles better than any other crap they wrote on the other printings.

6595: Ogre Arsonist.author: DarthParallax
6595: Ogre Arsonist.text_parsed:
Comparing it to Watchwolf I think is bad because Watchwolf was a 2 mana creature. Let's call it the equivalent of approx. {3} for the color-weight? This card is 5 mana in one color.

Calling this 'the Very Best Hill Giant Ever' makes a lot more sense- most of the decks I would play Watchwolf in, I would not play this card. In every conceivable situation I would consider running Hill Giant, even in Giant Tribal in a metagame where an Ogre-Hate card existed, I would play this card instead. In the same colors, for only {1} additional mana you are getting Sinkhole. That kind of value is not appropriate to even be calling it Stone Rain anymore, though it's not really like having a Strip Mine either. It's closer to a Strip Mine than a Stone Rain though.

6602: Goblin Lore.author: BastianQoU
6602: Goblin Lore.text_parsed: A buddy of mine made a R/U flashback deck recently, abusing all the new stuff from Innistrad/Dark Ascension. This would be a great way of drawing out cards, and is practically 'draw a card, put the top three cards of your library into your graveyard' with an empty hand. It nets you an extra card, but probably shouldn't be plaid if you have anything important in your hand. Three random discards is a pretty big risk. I'd say a solid 3 stars.

6607: Magma Giant.author: Kryptnyt
6607: Magma Giant.text_parsed:
You kind of have to compare this guy to Thunder Dragon, printed a set before this. Flying, one more damage to groundlings, two less damage to fliers and players.
Some people also hate it when they spend 7 on a creature and it dies to a Lightning bolt. Personally, I don't mind.
One of the advantages of Magma Giant over Thunder dragon is that thunder dragon kills Dragonspeaker Shamans, while Magma Giant will not kill Stinkdrinker Daredevils. It also makes MG a viable option over Thundercloud Shaman, which could kill the daredevils, though does not always do that.
I prefer the Fifth Dawn artwork though, he looks like "Red Naked Man Batheing in Velveeta"

6613: Bear Cub.author: yyukichigai
6613: Bear Cub.text_parsed:
To me, this little guy is way more appropriate than the existing vanilla-tacular Grizzly Bears. For something that's arguably one of the strongest non-magical creatures in the wild, 2/2 is a pretty low power/toughness. It makes more sense if its a young bear.

Also, he's freakin' adorable, which makes it somehow a ton more satisfying to make him swing at someone. "Aww, look at him mauling you. Who's a good face-ripping cutie? Who's a good face-ripping cutie?"

6620: Norwood Warrior.author: Ragamander

It hasn't aged well, although the art by the wondrous Rebecca Guay still looks pretty swell. 6621: Monstrous Growth.author: WraithBalor
6621: Monstrous Growth.text_parsed: I'm stumped and have a question here. I have 4 copies of this card. One is from the Portal set, and one is Starter 2000. The other 2 are where I'm running in to a problem. They have the squirrel picture, which means they must be from Starter 1999, Starter 2000, or Portal Second Age. They have a black line separating the text, which rules out 2000. They also have a star for the edition, and the artists name centered, which should mean they're 1999. However, they have a white border like 2000, instead of the black border it shows for 1999. Thoughts anyone? Did I find some misprints? Fluke copies? Or is the border being both colors in one printing common? And if it makes them any different, does it change the price on them at all? Thanks!

6633: Bee Sting.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
6633: Bee Sting.text_parsed:
It's a sorcery that only deals 2 damage for 4 mana. Really? Just because it's green you're going to give it a good rating? Now if it were like Damnation, a black version of Wrath of God with the same mana cost, I would give this one hell of a good rating. But look at it. It's a sorcery, 4 cost, 2 damage. This card is crap in every way crap can be. It's just crap covered up with a green leaf to make you think it might not be crap.

@djbon2112

Color pie is not an argument for the card being good. No one would ever have a use for this in green when you've got Mortal Wound, about 10 "destroy target creature with flying cards to combo with Island of Wak-Wak, Whirlwind, and nearly infinite options on artifact destruction with Liquimetal Coating. Green has a ton of removal options, 4 cost 2 damage sorcery is crap no matter what color it's in. This is a PORTAL CARD, they're pretty much all terrible. This one is just worse than usual.

6635: Sylvan Yeti.author: Mode
6635: Sylvan Yeti.text_parsed:
Another interesting thing other than Sylvan Yeti's similarities with Maro is his creature type development:
-Starter 1999: Elemental
-Portal Second Age: Beast
-Oracle: Yeti

I wonder if it started as an Elemental because it was based on Maro:
Maybe during development, it just had some codename and started as an elemental, and then happened to become a Sylvan Yeti, leaving the creature type unfitting.
(If that is even possible; both Starter and Classic: Sixth Edition (Maro's earliest print) are from 1999, and i'm not sure which of those sets came first.)

8395: Mountain.author: MisterAction
8395: Mountain.text_parsed:
Okay, so let me get this straight. Portal, in order to make itself more accessible to new players, added a bunch of reminder text to pre-existing cards (Armageddon), neutered cards by saying exactly when to use their fast effects (Goblin Firestarter), changed "block" to "intercept" (but then changed it back mid-block), added swords and shields to differentiate power and toughness (actually very thoughtful of them)...

...and then they DIDN'T say what a mountain does?
8395: Mountain.text_posted:
Okay, so let me get this straight.  Portal, in order to make itself more accessible to new players, added a bunch of reminder text to pre-existing cards ([autocard]Armageddon[/autocard]), neutered cards by saying exactly when to use their fast effects ([autocard]Goblin Firestarter[/autocard]), changed "block" to "intercept" (but then changed it back mid-block), added swords and shields to differentiate power and toughness (actually very thoughtful of them)...

...and then they DIDN'T say what a mountain does?
